content:
Hello, all!
I am a final year grad student, and I am new to Rust and to contributing. I have been reading a lot of Rust code over the past few days and my primary interest is in working with compilers, so coming here seemed like the natural choice. I have currently claimed https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/87211 and looking forward to fixing this asap. As the discussion points out, it seems to be a straightforward fix right now, but I can't wait to dig deeper.
I am really happy to be here. Cheers!

Hi folks!
Getting involved here and figuring it all out, just the involvement and writing some code.
So, if you have a good first time contributor issue to look at, let me know!
Greets!

Hello!
I cloned the repo and tried running ./x.py check after adding download-ci-llvm = true to my config.toml, and it seems that there is some issue with the fact that the location I cloned the repo into contains a space in the path. I cloned the repo into /foo/bar baz/rust/, and running ./x.py check gives me error: no such file or directory: baz/rust/etc (etc is in-place of other subdirectories)
I presume this might be because of missing double quotes in a shell script somewhere?
I tried building without download-ci-llvm = true, and I encountered the same issue after 20 minutes of compilation :(
This is probably https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/56650 - does it happen while building rustc_llvm?
I would recommend just not using a filepath with spaces for now

hi :wave: i'm a first time contributor and i've got a small pr open (just doc improvements): https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/88202 . it's been open for about 2 weeks now with no response; is there anything i can do to get it reviewed? thanks.
I am the author of https://github.com/steadylearner/Rust-Full-Stack and not using Rust a lot but was invited here.
If you need help or something, let me know.
Hi I'm looking to be able to help contribute, I'm looking into issues related to the standard library

Hey everyone. I was working on rustlings on the from_into.rs exercise:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rustlings/blob/main/exercises/conversions/from_into.rs

My solution resulted in this implementation of From:

impl From<&str> for Person {
    fn from(s: &str) -> Person {
        if s.is_empty() {
            return Default::default();
        }

        let mut split = s.split(",");

        let name: String = split.next().unwrap_or("").into();
        if name.is_empty() {
            return Default::default();
        }

        split.next()
            .and_then(|age| age.parse().ok())
            .and_then(|age| {
                match split.next() {
                    Some(_) => None,
                    None => Some(Person { name, age }),
                }
            }).unwrap_or(Default::default())
    }
}

But I though that instead of this...

split.next()
    .and_then(|age| age.parse().ok())
    .and_then(|age| {
        match split.next() {
            Some(_) => None,
            None => Some(Person { name, age }),
        }
    })
    .unwrap_or(Default::default())

... it would be nice to be able to do this ...

split.next()
    .and_then(|age| age.parse().ok())
    .and_then(|age| split.next().not(Person { name, age }))
    .unwrap_or(Default::default())

I figure this fits nicely along with the boolean like methods on Option like and, or, and xor. All we're missing is not

I created a PR and wanted to know what the rules were to submitting a PR to rust project.
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/94393

For library changes, see https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/blob/master/libs_changes.md

But TLDR for a small API addition that aren't changing/setting precedent, you can just send a PR following the general https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
@Edward Nicholes Jr. fyi, you can achieve the same functionality using split.next().ok_or(Person{ name, age }).err(). Although a dedicated method would certainly provide potentially better semantics

Hi, I am new to Rust but love the dev experience and the community so far. I have experience in full stack web development and 3D graphics. I would be happy to help and learn in any rust open source projects.
Martin Kletzander has marked this topic as resolved.
Martin Kletzander has marked this topic as unresolved.
